data.title: Party
data.text: Amazing days i remember when i was moved to new York city i love it that moment's :my name is alhaady haady

data.title: Full of history and ghosts
data.text: Had the privilege to work here for a year in a job that required overnight stays. If I had a weak hearth, I would've refused the job. The place is haunted, building is old and creaky. They used to have gallows in the basement where they held the most wanted criminals on death row. There are really nice old paintings all over the building of most mayors and governors that occupied the building at different times. Not sure if offered for tours, but if they do...take it!

data.title: Elegant designed building
data.text: Constructed in 18 century. Not far from Brooklyn bridge and municipal park ( or city hall park) is next to it. There is a subway stop for city hall. It is elegantly designed. However there is no tour for this building and there is security guard outside.

data.title: Understated
data.text: In the shadows of so many great buildings, old and new, the city hall looks unmoved.  The park is small. It's next to Brooklyn bridge, which attracts more people, local and tourists alike to walk.

data.title: Amazing Landmark!!!!!!
data.text: I visited New York City Hall Park, and you can't miss this building. Its architecture and location are impressive. The park is also very beautiful. The fountain in the middle of the park with those tall buildings as a background is the best spot for the coolest pictures. This is a must when visiting New York.

data.title: 34th Wedding Anniversary
data.text: Avra Estatorio - A great place for well prepared Greek  food served in a very pleasant surroundings. Octopus Salad, saga akin and Greek village salad great way to start a meal.  The Chicken souvlaki and lamb were great tasting.  Make this a must but expect to pay appropriately for a fine restaurant in NYC.

data.title: Reminder of a different vision for New York
data.text: City Hall seems out of place in the 21st century. It's a glimpse at a vision of New York that was not stuck in a grid with upward boxes and rectangles.

data.title: Surprisingly elegant
data.text: For a government building, this one is very elegant both on the exterior and interior.  Its surface is clean and white, already unusual for a NYC building,  The architecture is very classical and it has only three floors with a steeple.  Inside are spacious spiral staircases with bronze railings, very plush-feeling, and in the basement you can see the entire circular tile floor surrounded by elevators.  Also, there are town-hall meetings and other events open to the public.

data.title: easy access from metro station
data.text: NY city hall can be easily accessed from nearby subway station. It is not spectacular or anything but New York city hall.

data.title: Terrible Security
data.text: I was never even able to make it inside of this building, we were accosted by a security guard outside for taking a picture of the building. He stood over my shoulder and watched me delete the photo. I hope I can update my review someday with a better experience.

data.title: An Interesting Building, But Just a Building!
data.text: I would probably not go out of my way to go to see the New York City Hall.  Lots of important things get decided here, but you won't be part of those decisions.  Therefore, your only reason to go is to see something.... And that will not be exciting unless they have something on display, like when they had art works by the wonderful British contemporary artist Julian Opie spread around the grounds outside City Hall.

data.title: A bit of History
data.text: A remarkable building inside of the same park that bears its name, City Hall and Tweed Hall, are a must dee while touring downtown.

user_location.name: New York, New York, United States

data.title: One of the most unusual staircases in the United States
data.text:
-----The New York City Hall, a masterwork of marble, houses the offices of the mayor and is truly remarkable.  Finished in 1811, it is one of the oldest buildings in the City.  You may never see another staircase so beautiful and unique, the curving steps of which circle up and around in an arc, ascending and descending onto the ground floor with no supports.  The stones of the marble steps press against each other with a wide flat stone at its top (a true keystone) which holds the whole in place.  For four days when Abraham Lincoln's body lay in state on the large flat topstone, there was a steady stream of persons viewing his body, and many feared the staircase would collapse.  The building's architect was John McComb;  and I know of only one other work by him---the beautiful, white-columned, red-brick house on State Street near the Battery which now houses the shrine of Saint Elizabeth Ann  Seton.  In 1811, it was thought that the back of City Hall would seldom be seen because it was, at that time, so far north of the City; finally, in 1954, the bricks on its back (North) side were replaced by beautiful marble slabs matching those of the rest of the building and quarried from the same quarry in Vermont that was used originally.  On the second floor is a painting of Lafayette, the first ambassador from France to the United States following the French Revolution; it was painted by the man who invented the the Morse Code and is considered by some to be his masterpiece.  At a time when photography did not exist, Morse might have been considered one of the "official" painters of important persons in the United States, a kind of parallel, if you will, of the court painters in the old countries in Europe; the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art has another great work by Morse.
-----The keepers of the City Hall are wary of visitors (with good reason), but if you ask they will almost surely permit you to see the grand staircase and the Morse painting and the old horsehair sofa and chairs which were used by Governor Clinton more than a hundred years ago.
-----Nearby City Hall is the white terra cotta Woolworth Building of 1913; built by Cass Gilbert in his signature Moorish-and-Gothic style, it remained the world's tallest building until 1929.  Also nearby is the Brooklyn Bridge of 1883.
-----When I do walking tours of historic Brooklyn Heights, I include by the Woolworth Building and City Hall and the buildings of Newspaper Row.
Submitted by Joseph London, Licensed New York City Tour Guide and New York Historian

data.title: It's where it all began
data.text: It's hard to imagine this is where most of the decisions are made for what is such a big city but so we were told it is! The surroundings are brilliant with lots to see and do including coffee shops and bars etc. Take the tour and learn as much as you can, you never know there might be a pub quiz question related to something you hear one day

data.title: New York History at City Hall
data.text: This is basically where it all started, and this is where New York still is making decisions. As a tourist I cannot and do not want to interfere, but I just love to see and watch and explore where history began. And take the tour through City Hall with friends from abroad over and over. If anyone is interested, go to nyc.gov

data.title: klasse Gebäude
data.text: nur leider kommt man nicht richtig zum besichtigen ran. Alles streng abgeschirmt und bewacht. Um an ein gutes Foto zu gelangen, einfach die Parkanlage durchqueren. Hier kann man sich auch kurz erholen und den Anblick des Gbeäudes genießen.

data.title: Top!
data.text: Sehr interessantes Gebäude! Viel Geschichte dabei und sehr schön gemacht. Hier zahlt es sich aus sich etwas Zeit zu nehmen!

data.title: Waanzinnig mooi
data.text: Wat een waanzinnig mooi gebouw, dit stadhuis. De architect is echt boven zijn/haar niveau uitgestegen hier. Ook wat bevreemdend: Je zou namelijk bijna vergeten dat deze metropool natuurlijk gewoon een stad is en dus een stadhuis heeft. Het parkje ervoor is erg fijn om even soort-van aan de drukte te ontsnappen.

data.title: городская ратуша Нью Йорка
data.text: Большое историческое здание начала 19 века - одна из старейших ратушей на территории США, которая со дня постройки непрерывно используется по прямому назначению - тут заседает городское правительство Нью Йорка. Ратуша расположена недалеко от съезда с Бруклинского моста. Вокруг много всяких разных административных зданий - судов разной направленности, каких-то госконтор по делам мигрантов и т.п. В самом здании ратуши можно ознакомиться с историей США (для туристов - бесплатно, есть организованные экскурсии), а можно и заключить брак (для местных), т.к. кроме прочего там есть загс. Перед зданием разбит небольшой приятный парк.

data.title: Красивое, старинное здание
data.text:
В самом центре Манхэттена, рядом с Бруклинским мостом, можно посетить интересное место - здание и парк нью-йоркской ратуши.
 Здание привлекает своей стариной, построено в 18-19 веке. При ратуше также разбит небольшой, уютный парк.
